title: Stiff Person Syndrome
scope: ** Diagnostic workup and management of suspected or confirmed Stiff Person Syndrome and its spectrum disorders (classic SPS, stiff-limb syndrome, PERM) across all care settings. Covers initial evaluation, antibody testing (anti-GAD65, anti-amphiphysin, anti-DPPX, anti-glycine receptor), EMG findings, first-line symptomatic therapy (benzodiazepines, baclofen), immunotherapy (IVIg, rituximab, plasmapheresis), and management of acute exacerbations including status spasticus. For isolated cerebellar ataxia with anti-GAD antibodies or autoimmune epilepsy with anti-GAD antibodies, use respective templates. For tetanus or functional neurological disorder evaluation, use respective templates.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Metabolic screen; renal/hepatic function; pre-immunotherapy baseline
Primary diagnostic antibody; present in ~80% of classic SPS; titers >2000 IU/mL highly suggestive of SPS (vs. lower titers in T1DM, cerebellar ataxia)
Rhabdomyolysis from severe spasms; elevated during acute exacerbations
Screen for concurrent type 1 diabetes mellitus (30-60% comorbidity with SPS); pre-treatment baseline
Type 1 diabetes mellitus screening and monitoring (common autoimmune comorbidity)
Hypomagnesemia can exacerbate spasms; seizure threshold
Lactic acidosis from prolonged severe spasms
Myoglobinuria screen if rhabdomyolysis suspected; infection screen
Rule out infection (especially tetanus differential; pre-immunosuppression)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Paraneoplastic SPS marker; associated with breast cancer, lung cancer, thymoma; present in ~5% of SPS
PERM variant marker; associated with brainstem involvement, myoclonus, autonomic dysfunction
PERM variant with hyperexcitability, GI dysmotility, cognitive changes
Associated with SPS spectrum; seizures and encephalopathy
Associated with SPS spectrum; seizures; paraneoplastic

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Paraneoplastic antibody panel (Hu, Yo, Ri, CV2/CRMP5, Ma2) (CPT 86255)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Comprehensive paraneoplastic screen; amphiphysin-positive SPS is paraneoplastic
Baseline before IVIg; hypogammaglobulinemia screen before rituximab

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Hepatitis B surface antigen + core antibody (CPT 80074)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Reactivation risk before rituximab or immunosuppression

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Anti-GAD65 antibodies (paired CSF and serum with index) (CPT 86235)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Intrathecal anti-GAD production; CSF anti-GAD supports diagnosis; serum may be negative in rare cases with positive CSF
Neuromyotonia/Morvan syndrome differential; overlaps with SPS spectrum
Autoimmune encephalitis differential with seizures and movement disorder

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Genetic testing for hereditary hyperekplexia (GLRA1, GLRB, SLC6A5)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Hereditary hyperekplexia differential in early-onset cases
Commercial panels including GAD65, amphiphysin, DPPX, GlyR, GABA-A, GABA-B
Monoclonal gammopathy and lymphoproliferative disorder screen
Pheochromocytoma if paroxysmal hypertension with spasms (rare differential)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Assess for elevated ICP; typically normal in SPS
Rule out infection and inflammation; usually normal or mild pleocytosis in SPS
May be mildly elevated; rule out infectious meningitis
Rule out infectious meningitis; typically normal in SPS
Intrathecal anti-GAD synthesis; may be positive even when serum is negative; calculate CSF/serum ratio to confirm intrathecal production
Intrathecal IgG synthesis; may show CSF-specific bands in SPS; helps distinguish from MS
CNS lymphoma exclusion if atypical presentation

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without gadolinium (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.target: Typically NORMAL in classic SPS (important negative finding); may show cerebellar atrophy if anti-GAD cerebellar involvement; rule out structural lesions, MS, myelopathy

Essential/First-line.item: MRI spine (cervical and thoracic) with and without gadolinium (CPT 72156+72157)
Essential/First-line.target: Typically NORMAL in classic SPS; rule out myelopathy (compressive, inflammatory, vascular); may show cord signal in PERM variant
Continuous motor unit activity (CMUA) at rest in agonist and antagonist muscles simultaneously; no voluntary suppression; involuntary co-contraction pattern; motor units normal morphology
Malignancy screen (breast, lung, thymoma, lymphoma); especially if anti-amphiphysin positive
Baseline rhythm; QTc assessment; autonomic dysfunction

Extended.target: Breast cancer screening (paraneoplastic SPS, especially anti-amphiphysin)

Extended.item: CT chest with contrast (if not done above) (CPT 71260)

Extended.target: Occult malignancy (if paraneoplastic SPS suspected or anti-amphiphysin positive); breast, lung, thymoma, lymphoma
Testicular cancer screen if paraneoplastic suspected
Rule out epileptic origin of spasms; PERM variant may show encephalopathic changes; differentiate from epileptic myoclonus

Extended.item: Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) with inspiratory/expiratory pressures (CPT 94010+94060)
Extended.target: Respiratory muscle function; restrictive pattern from chest wall rigidity; assess ventilatory capacity

Extended.item: Skin biopsy (punch) for small fiber neuropathy (CPT 88305)
Extended.target: Intraepidermal nerve fiber density; SPS can coexist with small fiber neuropathy

Rare/Specialized.target: Cerebellar or brainstem hypermetabolism (PERM); cortical dysfunction
Distinguish epileptic vs. non-epileptic spasms; characterize movement phenomenology
Central sensory pathway assessment; spinal cord involvement

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute severe spasms; status spasticus; first-line benzodiazepine for SPS

dosing.instructions: 5-10 mg IV push over 2-5 minutes; may repeat q5-10 min PRN; max 30 mg in first hour; then transition to scheduled dosing; typical maintenance 10-30 mg PO TID-QID

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Respiratory depression without ventilator support; acute narrow-angle glaucoma; severe hepatic insufficiency; myasthenia gravis
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Respiratory rate; SpO2; sedation level; BP; airway patency; have flumazenil available

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute spasms; alternative to diazepam if IV diazepam unavailable; status spasticus

dosing.instructions: 2-4 mg IV push over 2 minutes; may repeat q5-10 min; max 8 mg in first hour; less lipophilic than diazepam (shorter CNS duration)

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Respiratory depression without ventilator support; acute narrow-angle glaucoma; severe hepatic insufficiency
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Respiratory rate; SpO2; sedation level; BP; airway patency

Acute/Emergent.indication: Status spasticus requiring continuous infusion; ICU setting

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg IV bolus, then 0.05-0.2 mg/kg/hr continuous infusion; titrate to spasm control; taper gradually over days once spasms controlled

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Respiratory depression (requires mechanical ventilation for continuous infusion); acute narrow-angle glaucoma
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Continuous SpO2; respiratory rate; BP; sedation level (RASS); ventilator settings

Acute/Emergent.indication: Refractory status spasticus not responding to benzodiazepines; ICU with mechanical ventilation

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg/kg IV bolus, then 20-50 mcg/kg/min infusion; titrate to spasm suppression; max 80 mcg/kg/min; avoid >48 hours at high doses

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Propofol allergy (egg/soy); propofol infusion syndrome risk >48h; hemodynamic instability
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Triglycerides q24h; CK; metabolic panel; lactate; propofol infusion syndrome (fever, rhabdo, metabolic acidosis, cardiac failure); hemodynamics

Acute/Emergent.item: IV crystalloid (normal saline or lactated Ringer)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Rhabdomyolysis prevention and treatment during severe spasms

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV crystalloid (normal saline or lactated Ringer) 250 mL/hr IV

dosing.instructions: 1-2 L bolus then 150-250 mL/hr; target urine output >200 mL/hr if CK >5000; add sodium bicarbonate 150 mEq/L NS if myoglobinuria
dosing.orderSentence: IV crystalloid (normal saline or lactated Ringer) 250 mL/hr IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: I/O; CK q6h; BMP q6-12h; urine myoglobin; urine output

Acute/Emergent.indication: Refractory spasms with hyperthermia or malignant hyperthermia-like presentation during severe SPS crisis

dosing.instructions: 1-2.5 mg/kg IV push; may repeat q5-10 min; max 10 mg/kg; transition to PO 25-100 mg QID when stabilized

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: First-line symptomatic therapy for rigidity and spasms in SPS; GABAergic mechanism addresses pathophysiology

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO TID; titrate by 5 mg/dose every 3-5 days as tolerated; typical effective dose 20-60 mg/day in divided doses; some patients require up to 100+ mg/day; max limited by sedation

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Respiratory depression; acute narrow-angle glaucoma; severe hepatic insufficiency; myasthenia gravis; severe OSA without CPAP
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; respiratory status; falls; cognitive function; tolerance; dependence (do NOT abruptly discontinue)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adjunctive to benzodiazepines for rigidity and spasms; GABA-B agonist

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO TID; increase by 5 mg/dose every 3-5 days; target 40-80 mg/day in divided doses; max 80 mg/day (higher doses off-label with close monitoring)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment (reduce dose); abrupt withdrawal causes seizures and hallucinations
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; weakness; renal function; do NOT discontinue abruptly (withdrawal seizures, hallucinations, autonomic instability)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adjunctive therapy for rigidity, spasms, and neuropathic pain; anticonvulsant with GABA-modulating properties

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q1-3d; target 900-1800 mg TID; max 3600 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; peripheral edema; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adjunctive therapy for rigidity, spasms, and neuropathic pain; alternative to gabapentin

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg BID; may increase q1wk; target 150-300 mg BID; max 600 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment (adjust dose); Class V controlled substance
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; weight gain; peripheral edema; dizziness; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adjunctive therapy for rigidity and spasms; alpha-2 adrenergic agonist muscle relaxant

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg PO TID; increase by 2-4 mg q3-7d; max 36 mg/day divided TID; take consistently with or without food

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Concurrent fluvoxamine or ciprofloxacin (CYP1A2 inhibitors); hepatic impairment
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, 1, 3, 6 months, then periodically; BP (hypotension); sedation; dry mouth

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adjunctive benzodiazepine for myoclonus (especially PERM variant); nocturnal spasms

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg PO BID; increase by 0.5 mg q3-5d; max 6 mg/day; useful for myoclonus in PERM variant

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Respiratory depression; severe hepatic disease; acute narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; ataxia; cognitive impairment; respiratory status; do NOT discontinue abruptly

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Myoclonus treatment (especially PERM variant); anti-seizure prophylaxis if cortical involvement

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg PO BID; increase by 500 mg/day q1-2wk; max 3000 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Behavioral changes (rage, irritability); suicidality; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Comorbid neuropathic pain; depression and anxiety (common in SPS)

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg PO daily x 1 week; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: BP; hepatic function; serotonin syndrome risk; suicidality monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Anxiety and depression comorbidity management; high prevalence in SPS patients

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg PO daily; increase by 25-50 mg q1-2wk; max 200 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Suicidality monitoring; serotonin syndrome risk; hyponatremia (SIADH) in elderly

Second-line/Refractory.indication: First-line immunotherapy for SPS; Class I evidence (Dalakas 2001 NEJM RCT); reduces stiffness and improves function

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg/day IV for 5 days (total 2 g/kg); infuse initial rate 0.5 mL/kg/hr, increase q30min by 0.5 mL/kg/hr to max 4 mL/kg/hr; premedicate with acetaminophen and diphenhydramine; repeat every 4-6 weeks for maintenance

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: IgA deficiency (anaphylaxis risk -- check IgA level); renal insufficiency (use sucrose-free); hypercoagulable states (thrombosis risk)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Renal function (BUN/Cr before each cycle); CBC; vital signs during infusion; headache (aseptic meningitis); DVT/PE risk; hemolysis (DAT, LDH, haptoglobin); IgA level before first infusion

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Acute severe SPS or status spasticus not responding to benzodiazepines and IVIg; removes pathogenic antibodies

dosing.instructions: 5 exchanges over 10-14 days (every other day); 1-1.5 plasma volume exchanges per session; albumin replacement (NOT FFP unless coagulopathy); central venous catheter required

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active sepsis; hemodynamic instability; heparin allergy (if used); unable to establish vascular access
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: BP and vitals during sessions; calcium (citrate-induced hypocalcemia); fibrinogen; coagulation studies; electrolytes; CBC; line infections

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Refractory rigidity and spasms not controlled by maximal oral medications; severe functional impairment

dosing.instructions: Trial: 50-100 mcg intrathecal bolus; if positive response, implant programmable pump; typical maintenance 100-800 mcg/day continuous infusion; titrate over weeks

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active infection; coagulopathy; CSF obstruction; patient unable to return for pump refills
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Pump function and refill schedule; withdrawal symptoms if pump malfunction (medical emergency -- similar to status spasticus); CSF leak; infection; catheter complications

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Focal refractory rigidity and spasms; specific muscle group targeting

dosing.instructions: Dose varies by muscle group; typical 50-200 units per large muscle (e.g., paraspinal); EMG/ultrasound-guided injection; repeat q12 weeks; onset 3-7 days, peak 2-4 weeks

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Systemic neuromuscular disease (relative); infection at injection site; known antibodies to botulinum toxin
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Weakness at injection site; dysphagia (if cervical muscles); distant spread effects; antibody development with repeated use

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.indication: Second-line immunotherapy for SPS; B-cell depletion reduces anti-GAD production; used when IVIg insufficient or for IVIg-sparing

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV x 2 doses (day 0 and day 14); repeat based on CD19/CD20 repopulation or clinical relapse (typically q6 months); premedicate with methylprednisolone 100 mg IV, acetaminophen 650 mg, diphenhydramine 50 mg

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.pretreatment: Hepatitis B serology; CBC, CMP; quantitative immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM); JCV antibody (PML risk); TB screening (QuantiFERON); pregnancy test; vaccination update (before initiating)
Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.contraindications: Active hepatitis B; severe active infection; live vaccines within 4 weeks; severe hypogammaglobulinemia (IgG <300)
Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.monitoring: Hepatitis B surveillance; CBC q2-4 weeks initially; immunoglobulin levels q3-6 months; CD19/CD20 B-cell counts q3 months; infusion reactions (slow rate if reaction); PML surveillance; infection monitoring

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.indication: Steroid-sparing immunosuppression; adjunctive to IVIg or rituximab

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg PO BID; increase by 500 mg every 2 weeks; target 1000-1500 mg BID (2000-3000 mg/day total); onset of effect 2-3 months

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.pretreatment: CBC, CMP, LFTs; pregnancy test; hepatitis B/C serology; TB screen
Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.contraindications: Pregnancy (Category D -- teratogenic); active infection; concurrent live vaccines
Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.monitoring: CBC q2 weeks x 3 months then monthly; LFTs; GI symptoms (diarrhea, nausea); infection surveillance; pregnancy prevention (two forms of contraception)

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.indication: Steroid-sparing agent; adjunctive immunotherapy for SPS

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg PO daily; increase by 50 mg every 2 weeks; target 2-3 mg/kg/day; onset of action 3-6 months

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.pretreatment: TPMT genotype/activity level; CBC, CMP, LFTs; hepatitis B/C; TB screen
Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.contraindications: TPMT deficiency (myelosuppression risk); concurrent allopurinol (reduce dose 75%); pregnancy (relative)
Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.monitoring: TPMT genotype before starting; CBC q2 weeks x 2 months then monthly; LFTs monthly; amylase if abdominal pain (pancreatitis)

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.indication: Adjunctive immunosuppression; short-term during acute flares; bridge while waiting for IVIg/rituximab effect; less effective as monotherapy for SPS

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg); taper by 10 mg every 2 weeks to 20 mg, then by 5 mg every 2-4 weeks; attempt to discontinue or reach lowest effective dose; avoid prolonged use (less effective for SPS than for other autoimmune conditions)

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.pretreatment: Active infection; uncontrolled diabetes; avascular necrosis; psychosis from steroids; PUD
Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.contraindications: Glucose; BP; weight; mood; bone density (DEXA if >3 months); ophthalmology (cataracts, glaucoma)

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.indication: Severe refractory SPS failing IVIg, rituximab, and other agents; last resort

dosing.instructions: 750 mg/m2 IV monthly for 6 cycles; pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA for uroprotection; adjust for renal function

Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.pretreatment: CBC, CMP, UA before each cycle; pregnancy test; fertility counseling; hepatitis B/C; TB screen
Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.contraindications: Pregnancy (Category D); active infection; bone marrow failure; bladder outlet obstruction
Disease-Modifying / Immunotherapy (Long-.monitoring: CBC weekly x 4 weeks after each cycle (nadir day 10-14); UA (hemorrhagic cystitis); BMP; LFTs; fertility preservation discussion; malignancy risk

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (neuroimmunology specialist) for diagnosis confirmation, antibody interpretation, immunotherapy guidance, and long-term management plan
Neuromuscular medicine for EMG/NCS to document continuous motor unit activity and confirm electrophysiologic diagnosis
Rheumatology or endocrinology for autoimmune comorbidity management (T1DM, thyroiditis, pernicious anemia, vitiligo)
Oncology for paraneoplastic evaluation and tumor management if anti-amphiphysin positive or malignancy identified
Physical therapy for gait training, flexibility, balance assessment, and fall prevention given rigidity and impaired mobility
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, assistive device evaluation, and energy conservation given functional limitations from rigidity
Pain management for refractory pain and spasms not responding to first-line agents
Psychiatry for anxiety and depression management; high prevalence of task-specific phobias and agoraphobia in SPS due to fear of triggering spasms
Pulmonology for respiratory function assessment if chest wall rigidity compromises ventilation
Anesthesiology consult for intrathecal baclofen pump trial and surgical planning if refractory to oral medications
Social work for disability resources, home health services, and insurance navigation for IVIg coverage
Ophthalmology for visual assessment if anti-GAD associated optic neuropathy or cerebellar involvement
Infusion center coordination for IVIg, rituximab, or cyclophosphamide outpatient infusions
Neurosurgery consultation for intrathecal baclofen pump implantation if ITB trial successful

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for uncontrolled spasms, difficulty breathing, falls with injury, or inability to walk (may indicate status spasticus requiring ICU care)
SPS is a chronic, treatable autoimmune condition -- improvement is expected with appropriate therapy but may take weeks to months; this is a lifelong condition requiring ongoing treatment
Do NOT stop benzodiazepines abruptly as this may trigger life-threatening status spasticus (severe unrelenting spasms, respiratory failure); always taper under physician supervision
Avoid known triggers for spasms: sudden loud noises, unexpected touch, emotional stress, cold temperatures, sudden movements, and crowded environments
Report signs of infection immediately (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria, rash) as immunosuppressive therapy (IVIg, rituximab) increases infection risk
Do not drive until cleared by neurology due to risk of sudden spasms, impaired mobility, and medication sedation effects
Keep a spasm diary tracking frequency, severity, triggers, and medication effects to guide treatment optimization
Monitor blood sugars regularly if diabetic or if starting corticosteroids (steroids significantly elevate blood glucose; SPS has high T1DM comorbidity)
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive therapy including rituximab and mycophenolate; inform all physicians and pharmacists of immunosuppression status
Carry medical alert identification (bracelet/card) indicating Stiff Person Syndrome, current medications (especially benzodiazepines and immunotherapy), and emergency contact information
Attend all follow-up appointments -- SPS requires regular monitoring with labs, clinical assessments, and periodic antibody levels
In case of surgery or medical procedure, inform anesthesiologist about SPS (risk of exacerbated spasms with certain anesthetic agents; benzodiazepines must NOT be withheld perioperatively)
Avoid alcohol as it potentiates benzodiazepine sedation and increases fall risk

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Gentle stretching and range-of-motion exercises daily to maintain flexibility and reduce rigidity; avoid high-impact or startling exercises
Warm-water pool therapy (aquatic physical therapy) as tolerated -- warmth and buoyancy reduce spasm frequency and severity
Fall prevention measures at home (remove loose rugs, adequate lighting, grab bars in bathroom, non-slip mats) given rigidity and balance impairment
Stress management techniques (meditation, deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, cognitive behavioral therapy) as emotional stress is a common spasm trigger
Adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly); maintain regular sleep schedule; benzodiazepine dosing may need evening adjustment for nocturnal spasms
Low-impact exercise program as tolerated (walking, stationary cycling, yoga with modifications) to prevent deconditioning from immobility
Temperature regulation: avoid extreme cold which can trigger spasms; dress in layers; maintain comfortable ambient temperature
Assistive device evaluation (cane, walker, wheelchair) based on functional status and fall risk to maintain independence and safety
Vaccinations should be up to date before initiating immunosuppressive therapy (pneumococcal, influenza, hepatitis B, COVID-19); avoid live vaccines on immunosuppression
Bone protection with calcium and vitamin D if on chronic corticosteroids; DEXA scan if steroid use >3 months
Smoking cessation to improve respiratory function and reduce infection risk during immunosuppression
Support group referral: Stiff Person Syndrome Research Foundation (stiffperson.org) for peer support and disease education

differential.features: Relapsing-remitting course; white matter lesions on MRI; oligoclonal bands; optic neuritis; Lhermitte sign; spasticity from upper motor neuron damage (not rigidity)
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine (periventricular lesions, Dawson fingers); CSF oligoclonal bands; anti-GAD negative; no continuous motor unit activity on EMG

differential.features: Upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski, spasticity); sensory level; bowel/bladder dysfunction; structural cause on imaging
differential.tests: MRI spine (cord compression or signal change); normal EMG (no CMUA); anti-GAD negative

differential.features: Acute onset; history of wound/infection; trismus (lockjaw); opisthotonus; risus sardonicus; no antibody elevation; self-limited with treatment
differential.tests: Wound culture; tetanus toxin assay; history of incomplete vaccination; anti-GAD negative; EMG may show CMUA but resolves with treatment

differential.features: Peripheral nerve hyperexcitability; myokymia; fasciculations; sweating; muscle cramps; anti-CASPR2/anti-LGI1 antibodies; no axial rigidity predominance
differential.tests: EMG (neuromyotonic discharges, myokymic discharges); anti-CASPR2/LGI1 antibodies; anti-GAD negative; distinct EMG pattern from SPS

differential.features: Inconsistent symptoms; entrainment; distractibility; positive Hoover sign; no continuous motor unit activity at rest; normal antibodies
differential.tests: EMG normal at rest; anti-GAD negative; positive functional neurological examination findings (Hoover, tremor entrainment); psychiatric comorbidity common

differential.features: Progressive spasticity; upper motor neuron signs; no sensory involvement; slow progression over years; no antibody positivity; no episodic spasms
differential.tests: EMG (no CMUA; upper motor neuron pattern); anti-GAD negative; MRI (motor cortex atrophy); slow progression

differential.features: Family history; progressive lower extremity spasticity; insidious onset; genetic mutations identified
differential.tests: Genetic testing (SPG genes); anti-GAD negative; EMG normal at rest; family history

differential.features: Axial rigidity from joint/ligament pathology; inflammatory back pain; sacroiliac involvement; HLA-B27 positive
differential.tests: X-ray/MRI of sacroiliac joints; HLA-B27; ESR/CRP elevated; anti-GAD negative; EMG normal

differential.features: Rigidity (lead-pipe, cogwheel); bradykinesia; resting tremor; asymmetric onset; dopamine-responsive
differential.tests: DAT scan; clinical features (bradykinesia required); anti-GAD negative; EMG shows no CMUA; L-dopa trial

differential.features: Sustained or intermittent muscle contractions causing abnormal postures; task-specific; patterned movements; may have sensory tricks
differential.tests: EMG (patterned co-contraction during movement, not continuous at rest); DYT gene testing; anti-GAD negative; different movement pattern

differential.features: Difficulty relaxing muscles; grip myotonia; percussion myotonia; genetic basis; no startle-induced spasms
differential.tests: EMG (myotonic discharges -- dive-bomber sound); genetic testing (DMPK, CNBP, SCN4A, CLCN1); anti-GAD negative

differential.features: Exaggerated startle response from birth/infancy; neonatal stiffness; genetic (GLRA1, GLRB); no progressive rigidity; responds to clonazepam
differential.tests: Genetic testing (glycine receptor mutations); onset in infancy; anti-GAD negative; EMG (startle reflex but no CMUA at rest)

differential.features: Acute onset; recent neuroleptic use; hyperthermia; autonomic instability; CK markedly elevated; encephalopathy
differential.tests: Medication history (neuroleptic exposure); CK markedly elevated; hyperthermia; resolves with drug discontinuation

differential.features: Acute onset; serotonergic drug exposure; clonus (especially lower extremity); hyperreflexia; hyperthermia; agitation
differential.tests: Medication history (serotonergic drugs); clonus (distinct from rigidity); resolves with drug discontinuation and cyproheptadine

monitoring.item: Spasm frequency and severity assessment (clinical scoring)

disposition.criteria: Spasms controlled on oral medications; able to ambulate safely (with or without assistive device); ADLs independent or with available home support; no respiratory compromise; CK trending down; follow-up with neurology within 1-2 weeks; medication education completed; triggers identified and avoidance plan discussed; family/caregiver education completed

New-onset SPS requiring diagnostic workup (LP, EMG, antibodies, imaging); uncontrolled spasms requiring IV benzodiazepines or medication titration; need for IVIg initiation; elevated CK from spasm-related rhabdomyolysis; functional decline requiring inpatient rehabilitation evaluation; new paraneoplastic workup needed

Status spasticus (severe unrelenting spasms); respiratory compromise from chest wall rigidity; need for mechanical ventilation; rhabdomyolysis with CK >10,000 or acute kidney injury; autonomic instability; need for continuous benzodiazepine or propofol infusion; PERM variant with encephalopathy and autonomic dysfunction

Neuroimmunology specialist not available; neuromuscular EMG expertise not available; IVIg/plasmapheresis not available; intrathecal baclofen pump services not available; ICU care required when not available at current facility

Significant functional impairment from rigidity and spasms; medically stable; expected to benefit from intensive PT/OT; unable to safely return home; needs supervised medication titration and mobility training

All discharged patients: neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; labs per monitoring schedule; ongoing IVIg scheduling if initiated; physical therapy referral; paraneoplastic screening completion if not done inpatient

Uncontrolled spasms despite medication compliance; respiratory difficulty; falls with injury; status spasticus; suspected rhabdomyolysis (dark urine, severe muscle pain after spasms); infection on immunosuppression
